title: Acute Limb Ischemia
diagnosis_topic: Acute Arterial Occlusion with Limb Ischemia
setup_script: A 65-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation and hypertension presents with sudden onset of severe pain, pallor, and numbness in her right leg that began 4 hours ago. She reports no trauma. She takes warfarin but admits to missing doses. Current medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for vital signs
dynamic_flow.reply: BP 130/75 mmHg, HR 95 bpm irregularly irregular, RR 18, Temp 36.8 °C, SpO₂ 97% on room air.
Right leg is cool and pale with mottling to mid-calf, capillary refill >4 sec, absent Doppler signals distally, diminished sensation, motor weakness present.
CBC and BMP normal, INR 1.4, lactate 3.2 mmol/L.
Bedside Doppler shows absent arterial flow; duplex ultrasound confirms acute occlusion of the common femoral artery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates systemic anticoagulation with heparin
dynamic_flow.reply: Pain stabilizes, though motor deficit persists.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays anticoagulation or intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: The limb becomes progressively mottled with fixed staining, and numbness worsens, suggesting impending necrosis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults vascular surgery and plans emergent revascularization
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is taken to the OR for embolectomy versus catheter-directed thrombolysis, depending on limb viability.
Atrial fibrillation predisposes to emboli. Other causes include in-situ thrombosis and trauma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about alternative imaging
dynamic_flow.reply: CT angiography may define anatomy but should not delay intervention.
Pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, poikilothermia, and paralysis are all present.
Fogarty catheter embolectomy removes clot, with restoration of pulsatile flow distally.
Monitor for reperfusion injury and compartment syndrome; continue anticoagulation and evaluate for cardiac source of embolus.
Fasciotomy is indicated if compartment pressures rise after reperfusion.
Postoperatively, potassium rises to 6.5 mmol/L and urine output declines, suggesting reperfusion syndrome.

critical_decision_points: Rapid recognition of acute limb ischemia and six P’s.
Imaging to define anatomy without delaying intervention.
Timely selection of embolectomy versus thrombolysis.
Anticipation and management of reperfusion injury and compartment syndrome.
